>
> Members of the list have rightly been sceptical of my=
 find as it is 
> almost
> unheard of in the West, if I had not seen it mys=
elf I would not have
> believed it either. I have seen many swords with Mur=
omachi/Momoyama style
> koshirae over the years, but 99.9% have been 19th c=
. swords in retro 
> style.
> Two exceptions come to mind: Victor Harris an=
d I catalogued the blades in
> the Museum of Japanese Sword Fittings in Tok=
yo for Christie's in '05. In
> that collection was a Momoyama tachi koshira=
e that was later sold in 
> NY, the
> other was an itomaki tachi made for a=
n Ikeda Daimyo in Christie's London.
> Victor has seen this nagamaki and ag=
rees that it is 16th c.
>
> I think this weapon is the first of a number of=
 identical contract pieces
> for an armoury, as it is numbered '1' as are o=
ne seppa, the fuchi and the
> tsuka in ink under the fuchi, it is utilitari=
an, with thin yamagane 
> mounts
> and low quality lacquer, the nakago-ana =
are not well made. The long ububa
> can be accounted for by its lack of use=
, it may have been polished 
> only once
> or twice then stored for a very =
long time, this would account for its 
> fairly
> good condition apart from=
 the leather tsuka binding shrinking and being
> attacked by insects.
>
> I=
t may look like a sword but it has the thick saya of a polearm, no 
> kurik=
ata
> and the tsuka is 21.5" long.
>
> As I stated in my earlier post it we=
ighs around 6lbs, this is not 
> something
> one would want as a personal w=
eapon, it is too heavy and awkward to carry
> and I think would only be use=
ful in battle.
